Posts.Content: Denali wrote: No, not because my chemo is finished.  In fact it hasn't even begun yet. But after my right side mastectomy Jan 16th, my left breast started discharging a clear fluid---only a drop every few days, but i thought it was normal because my drain was still in and figured my chest was full of fluid.  Not so.  Surgeon scheduled an MRI last Monday, the result of which I had to get ASAP because my port was to be surgically placed on Weds (yesterday).  After waiting on pins and needles all day Tues (another Xanex day), the results finally came in and the dr  called after 6pm.  And it was clear!  That means I have one GOOD boob! For the last week I didn't know whether I'd be going in for another mastectomy or a port placement.  Thank goodness it was the latter.  It went great and I don't remember a thing! Today I'm feeling no pain and going to a Sewing/Quilting Festival this afternoon.  MUGA test is Tues of next wk and if I pass that, chemo will begin Thurs.  So having my fun until then! Linda, Began TCH Feb 12, 2009 Dx 1/9/2009, IDC, 3cm, Stage IIA, Grade 3, 0/2 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Doing the Happy Dance! Denali Emily2008

Posts.Content: Feb 15, 2009 01:51AM Denali wrote: I arrived at the dr's at 10 and left about 4:30.  But I think it was because it was my first time and they gave me an information session and I thought some relaxant drugs, which I don't know if they give them to you every time.  They'd told me it would be about 4 hrs.  No, the Neulasta is a shot given at least 24 hrs after chemo, which helps the white blood cells.   Decadron is the sterioid taken the day before, day of and day after chemo in tablet form.  And let me tell you, my last pills were taken at noon yesterday and I'm still on a high!  I only got 4 hrs sleep last night but I'm still not tired.  My daughter helped me clean out my whole pantry today AFTER we had my WIG party! A couple female relatives and I went to the wig store and had a ball picking out wigs and hair colors!  I ordered one and it'll be here in plenty of time before my hair falls out!  Also I want to order some hats and scarves from:   www.tlcdirect.org  While at the store an older woman came in alone.  Come to find out she'd had BC 5 yrs ago and her hair has never been the same so her husband and she had planned to pick out a wig for her.  But he died suddenly in December.  Poor thing started tearing up so we all gave her huigs and I invited her to join me and my Red Hatters who meet for Happy Hour (dinner) every Tuesday.  We helped her pick out a wig and she left with a huge smile on her face.  I'll call her tomorrow.
Posts.Title: Starting TCH in Feb 2009? (Taxotere, Carboplatin, Herceptin) Denali Smile2006

Posts.Content: Denali wrote: Seems like the other thread of chemos beginning this month are mostly on the AC regimen.  Since the side effects could be so different, I thought it would be nice to be able to share our own experiences with Taxotere, Carboplatin and Herceptin. I will be getting TCH every 3 wks for 6 treatments, however, I'll be getting Herceptin every week (so in wk 2 and 3 between chemos).  After chemo, I'll get Herceptin every 3 wks to complete a year.   whoo.  Are we ready for this journey?? I had my first chemo yesterday and it went GREAT!  I didn't even feel it when they poked into my port because they froze it first.  They drew 3 vials of blood out and then began the IV. I'm going in for my Neulasta shot today and I've read it can cause awful bone aches, but they advised me to take Alleve and Claritan the day before, the day of and the after  the shot.  Hopefully, it'll work because I'm planning a wig party tomorrow.  I'm taking my daughter and friend to the wig shops with me and then meeting others for lunch.  I hope to hear from others on this regimen!  Maybe we can share SEs and reliefs.  Or just VENT to each other!  Linda, Began TCH Feb 12, 2009 Dx 1/9/2009, IDC, 3cm, Stage IIA, Grade 3, 0/2 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Starting TCH in Feb 2009? (Taxotere, Carboplatin, Herceptin) Denali Smile2006

Posts.Content: Feb 14, 2009 01:44AM Denali wrote: Welcome, Nonni!  I guess there's just not that many of us on TCH, huh?  I got my Neulasta shot today--will you get those the day after chemo too?  Kind of burned but not too bad.  I think the port has me spoiled.  Never felt a thing during chemo. I got sooooo much good info at my chemo appt--an hour and half sesion during the IV.  I've also gotten LOTS of good info on this board too.  But the board made me afraid of the Neulasta SEs.  When I asked the nurse today though, she said she's only known one pt with bone aches.  So we'll see. Herceptin seems to affect your nails a lot, so they advised me to get Sally Hansens Hard As Nails clear polish for them.  I'll be giving myself a manicure while watching TV tonight! I'm so glad to hear from you, Nonnie.  Nothing like someone else going through the same thing at the same time.  You should get one similar wig and one wild one.  Knock their socks off, Nonnie!
Posts.Title: Starting TCH in Feb 2009? (Taxotere, Carboplatin, Herceptin) Denali Smile2006

Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2009 01:58PM Denali wrote: Yesterday was awful for me.  Got to church in the morning but then in the afternoon I started crashing.  Achey all over.  I finally took some Alleve (and a Xanex) to be able to sleep.  Ugh.  searching the board today for sources of relief.  So please advise, if you have any tips. My friend's church makes up these Valentine bags every year for chemo patients and one was delivered to me yesterday.  Had lotion, soap, chocolate, cards, hat and all kinds of goodies in it.  What a wonderful thing they do.  I insisted on an address so I could send a thank you card.  There's so many good people in the world!
Posts.Title: Starting TCH in Feb 2009? (Taxotere, Carboplatin, Herceptin) Denali Smile2006

Posts.Content: Feb 14, 2009 04:45AM Denali wrote: jkcrml:  Neulasta is a shot you get the day after chemo, which is supposed to maintain your white blood cells, I believe.  As you know low white blood cells is a big side effect of chemo, putting you at greater risk with all the germs out there.  My nurse told me to not even order salads in restaurants anymore!  She said unless you've washed it yourself, don't eat raw food.  While we could have handled the germs before, we won't be able to when we're on chemo. duneoaks:  Thanks for pointing that out.  I saw that thread and have been reading it.  I just thought it would be neat to go through this with others who are beginning at the same time.
Posts.Title: Starting TCH in Feb 2009? (Taxotere, Carboplatin, Herceptin) Denali Smile2006

Posts.Content: Feb 15, 2009 04:27AM - edited Feb 15, 2009 04:32AM by Denali Smile:  We have the same chemo birthday!  I started on Feb 12th too.  And I'm still high on the steroid.  When my daughter came over this morning, she said it was like I was on speed.  A woman at chemo gets hers on Thursdays too and she said you crash by Monday.   So I have plenty of movies and Judge Judys recorded to watch during my down time.  BTW, did your face and neck flush from the Neulasta or steroid?  My face and neck have been red since yesterday--and I promise I haven't been drinking!  JKCML:  I'm still feeling fine from the chemo.  And yes, they tell you to eat before you go and you can even eat when you're getting it.  I didn't take anything with me, but the nurse asked if she could go next door to Wendy's, to get me some lunch!  I just never imagined I'd be eating during chemo! I've started a journal to record what I feel like each day of the 3 wk cycle, so I'll know what to expect and how to plan the next few months.  I guess we could count on doing ALL our housework during those steroid days, huh?
Posts.Title: Starting TCH in Feb 2009? (Taxotere, Carboplatin, Herceptin) Denali Smile2006

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2009 12:20AM Denali wrote: Today is better than yesterday afternoon--less achiness!  Is it for you all too?  You're a GREAT sister for doing this for her.  It's SOOOO much easier to look up scary medical info when it's for others and not for yourself! I'm almost done with my laundry!  Never thought I'd be so proud of that accomplishment.  Took some Alleve to help.
Posts.Title: Starting TCH in Feb 2009? (Taxotere, Carboplatin, Herceptin) Denali Smile2006

Posts.Content: Denali wrote: Someone gave me a book called It's Not About the Hair by Debra Jarvis.  It's a WONDERFUL, humorous book written by a woman who works as a chaplain (a very funny chaplain) at a cancer center and then is diagnosed with breast cancer herself. She tells her friends about her chemo of CMF, which stands for Cytoxan, methotrexate and 5-fluorouracil.  But she says she really knows it stands for Crushed cockroach, Monkey vomit and Floor sweepings. I have to think of something for mine:  TCH.  We can have fun with this.  What are YOU taking and what do you think it REALLY is?? Linda, Began TCH Feb 12, 2009 Dx 1/9/2009, IDC, 3cm, Stage IIA, Grade 3, 0/2 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Let's Do This..... Denali Denali

Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2009 03:27PM - edited Mar 4, 2009 03:28PM by Denali I take TCH, which really is:    T =  tarantula tears   C =  crushed cockroaches   H =  hamster hair
Posts.Title: Let's Do This..... Denali Denali

Posts.Content: May 14, 2009 08:45PM Denali wrote: The subject of answering people who ask how are you're doing--let me tell you my story.  It was somewhere after Chemo #1 or 2 and when I went to church, 2 or 3 good friends came up in a row and each asked that question.  Well, after talking over and over about my couple side effects I'd been feeling (nosebleeds and chapped hands), it was like setting the table for a Pity Party!  By the time I got into the church service, I was bawling!  I had to leave right away in tears. I learned that when folks ask you how you are, keep it short--good, ok, hanging in there.  I give all the details on my webpage, where folks can check if they want to.  There are several places on the web that will provide a free webpage for cancer patients.  Mine is on MyLIfeLine.org.  It has an update page, photo page, place folks can leave messages for you and even a calendar that you can ask for rides or help.
Posts.Title: What we wish we had known about chemo before we started! ddlatt kerry_lamb

Posts.Content: May 14, 2009 08:30PM Denali wrote: The most likely reason why your chance of recurrence is so high (even if it's not quite as high as your dr said) is the size of your tumor and the positive nodes.  When I asked my surgeon about my oncotype, he said it's not a factor because my tumor was so big (3.5 cm).  I've LOST weight--20 pounds!  Hurrah!  Ok, part of the weight loss was my right boob taken during my mastectomy.  But I could still lose another 20 and I wouldn't be hurting.  I was sort of hoping to get the emaciated look with chemo.  Then they'd have to BEG me to eat.   I hated the first round of steroids.  My daughter said I acted like I was on speed and it just didn't feel good to me at all.  But on the bright side, I cleaned my house spic & span.  I told my oncologist about it and she allowed me to just take have the dose.  So if the steroids bother you, tell your dr!  I just got Chemo #5 out of 6 and I'm still taking just half the steroid.  It's done me well.  I've never thrown up during my chemo crash, I just don't feel like eating, therefore I end up losing weight.
Posts.Title: Confused and need Answers Please Help! Shanagirl Sukiann

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2009 05:08PM Denali wrote: I had a single mastectomy on Jan 16th, about the same time you had your surgery and I'm having the same experience.  I was much more sore in later weeks than the first week.  Feels so much better when I'm at home and don't have to wear a bra or camisole under my shirt!   It's gotta get better soon!
Posts.Title: More sore one month after mastectomy Nana7 barbe1958

Posts.Content: May 10, 2009 05:07AM Denali wrote: When someone stupidly asks, "Is that a wig?" Our appropriate response should be, "Have you gained 20 pounds??"
Posts.Title: Things that crack me up...stories plz Lursa5 angicpa

Posts.Content: Feb 28, 2009 05:56PM Denali wrote: Karen, our pathology reports are very similar.  My oncologoist gave me a chart with statistics entitled Shared Decision Making: Decision:  No Additional Therapy - 53 out of 100 women will relapse (more cancer) in 10 yrs; and 43 will be alive and without cancer; 4 will die of other causes. Decision: Chemo and Hormonal Therapy - the 43 women above PLUS 35 women of 100 will be without cancer. I decided to go with the latter and do all I can to be in that 78 of the 100 cancer free in 10 yrs.
Posts.Title: Anyone declining further treatment after bilateral? karen_3 Jamie6

Posts.Content: May 31, 2009 01:58PM Denali wrote: For healthy treats how about carrot cake cupcakes??  If you could do it, it would be fun to surprise her and take along some photos of her in her younger years.  Share them with nurses and patients.  They'll love it and so will she.  Take a boa for her to wear or put around her chair during treatment. What a wonderful daughter you are!
Posts.Title: Chemo on Birthday-Need Ideas! shopper16 Denali

Posts.Content: May 31, 2009 01:51AM Denali wrote: Ellen, you must be frazzled.  Insist on getting the PET appt (and resuts) ASAP to put your mind at ease. The rise in markers is probably something unrelated to cancer as you just finished chemo.  Now think of all the times you worried yourself silly about something which turned out fine.  This could very well be one of those times!  Until you get the appt and results, read lots of books and watch lots of movies to distract your mind.  We're here for you!  Let us know how you're doing!
Posts.Title: Finished chemo- Tumor markers up? HELP REKoz LakeArrowheadgirl

Posts.Content: Denali wrote: I had my right side mastectomy 3 days ago (Jan 16th) and I'm doing well.  My adult kids have been great.  Even in a pre-op we were laughing.  The nurse handed me a marker and told me to write 'yes' on the breast to be removed.  I asked if I could write something like, " It's been great" or "bye-bye boobie" and she said no.  But we had her laughing too. Dr said he saw no evidence with the dye and radioactive stuff that my lymph nodes were affected!  I was on cloud 9 with that news!  Of course they could still find something in the lab, but based on what he saw, he did a simple mastectomy instead of a modified radical.  I don't have the pathology report yet so I don't know if it's hormone receptive. I got a little depressed this morning, thinking I'll most likely have to have chemo.  I really dread that not just for the hair loss, but the damage it could cause to the heart, cause diabetes, etc.  Took a Xanex and that helped. Questions:  How long do you drain after surgery?  Dr office says not to make a post-op appt until my drainage is 25ml or less per day.  I just took the dressing off and it looks awful, of course.  Looks like blood settled in area below the incision.  Is that normal?  Parts look yellowish too, but I suppose that's the iodine stuff they use during surgery? My son says that I'm officially an Amazon!  Legend has it that the Amazons was a fierce tribe of women warriors, who would cut off their right breast to better use the bow and arrow.  So that's me:  a fierce Amazon. Linda, Began TCH Feb 12, 2009 Dx 1/9/2009, IDC, 3cm, Stage IIA, Grade 3, 0/2 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: 3 days after surgery Denali barbe1958

Posts.Content: Feb 26, 2009 05:49PM Denali wrote: You're in the toughest stage:  waiting for results.  Please let us know how you do. In the meantime DISTRACT yourself!  Go to a movie or watch movies on TV.  Anything to get you to tomorrow! Sending positive thoughts your way!
Posts.Title: I'm so worry ... latin40 corbin02

Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2009 05:15PM Denali wrote: So sorry you're having to deal with such insensitve dorks for doctors!  I think you should finish your treatment and go back and give 'em heck.  In fact I'll come help you, when I finish my chemo, k? My surgeon mentioned lumpectomy first to me.  But I'd had a benign tumor removed from the same breast 4 yrs ago, and now I learned I had an IDC tumor in the same breast.  I decided to have a mastectomy on that side.  I'm 60, divorced and have no babies to nurse.  It just made sense to me.  After my mastectomy (2 wks ago) they found that I had DCIS in that breast also, of which they were unaware before surgery.  If I hadn't gotten a mastectomy, they'd have had to go back in! When I was getting the dye injected just before I went into surgery, I mentioned to the Dr in the breast care ctr of my decision for a mastectomy and she said good!  She said that in all her yrs of practice she'd never heard one woman say she regretted having the mastectomy.  But she and the nurses had heard lots of women who regretted just having a lumpectomy.  So do what feels right to you.
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed with ILC & need doctor references cat08 Firni

Posts.Content: Jan 11, 2013 03:12PM Denali wrote: I remember Apple from our Feb 2009 chemo group too.  Every time I've been back on the boards during the last 4 yrs, I have always checked in on Apple.  I guess I was a stalker but in a good way.  She's always been my private inspiration.  Now I wished that I'd let her know what she meant to me.  Now I'm crying tears of love for her.  May she and her family have peace.
Posts.Title: Has anyone heard from Apple? marie5890

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2009 03:29AM Denali wrote: Kelty, it sounds like our conditions are similar with our mastectomies on the same day.  I just received part of the pathology rpt today and instead of 2cm it was 3.5cm.  They also found DCIS and she said it was a good thing I insisted on a mastectomy or they'd be going back in to remove the breast.  The one good thing is they confirmed that it hadn't gone into any lymph nodes. The pain isn't half as bad as I'd thought it would be.  Glad to hear you have help with your little ones.  I couldn't imagine.....I feel so lucky I'm retired and my kids are grown--I'm 60. Feeling depressed with the new info, chemo will definitely be in my future.
Posts.Title: 3 days after surgery Denali barbe1958

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2009 11:17AM Denali wrote: GWing - this board has been a godsend to me.  I'm totally addicted and check it a hundred times a day!   I went in for my follow-up appt and even though I was still draining about 35-40 ml per day, he pulled it out.  I asked if I should use Kotex pads now that the drain is out and he just laughed and said no, to just use a simple dressing.  So I guess it's getting absorbed somehow, because it hasn't gone through the bandage. Love it that I don't have to wear pockets to hold the 'grenade' anymore.
Posts.Title: 3 days after surgery Denali barbe1958

Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2009 09:32AM Denali wrote: Bonita, you need some Xanex!  Call your dr for a prescription.  When I was diagnosed, I couldn't stop crying.  (Puff tissues will not go out of business anytime soon!)  My daughter had to call my dr for me.  The Xanex really helps you get through the inititial period--along with your support system. This board has also inspired me immensely.  I think of every woman who posts on this board as a warrior.  We gain strength from each other. Let us know how it goes for you.  Keep reading this board--there's so much info from the 'warriors' and it'll help you to know what to expect ahead, which helps the anxiety. Just know we're all rootin' for you.
Posts.Title: My mind my thoughts Bonita69 Bonita69

Posts.Content: Feb 27, 2009 06:32PM Denali wrote: Wonderful news!  Congrats!  Surgery will be a piece of cake--you don't remember a thing!  You'll sail through it!
Posts.Title: I'm so worry ... latin40 corbin02

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2009 03:06PM Denali wrote: I had a single mastectomy and can happily report that the pain isn't bad at all.  They'll give her pain meds, if she feels any pain after surgery.  They'll also give her something to calm her down before surgery.  Nurses will give you instructions on how to work the drains--very simple, really.  I was shocked at how easy my surgery and recovery was compared to what I'd expected. She needs you. Just be there for her.  She'll do fine.
Posts.Title: Nervous...Mom Having Surgery Tomorrow Jadai Jadai

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2012 12:06PM Denali wrote: Kristen, I burst out crying when they told me I was HER 2 positive!  Then the nurse explained it's really a GOOD thing because Herceptin is very effective.  It's like an extra tool in the toolbox that you can use to fight the cancer.  Since then, the more I read, the more I was convinced. Take the valium!  I can't emphasize that enough!  My Xanex has been my best friend.  I don't use it all the time (except when I was at your stage of the journey--after diagnosis), but on my 'low' days I know it's there for me and it really helps.  Goodness, don't think of it as aiding cancer, STRESS aids cancer.  I promise once you're done with surgery and on a treatment plan your nerves will calm down.  You're at the most stressful time so take care of yourself and use the meds when you need them.  Also, keep visiting the boards.  We know what you're going through. Stay strong!  You can do this!
Posts.Title: Diagnosed and scared kfontaine bluepearl

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2009 04:55PM Denali wrote: This is standard procedure.  They take the first one before chemo and use as a baseline.  During chemo it's taken to see if there are any changes. Try not to  worry.
Posts.Title: Muga Scan test 1/2 way through Chemo? Scrappygrl Scrappygrl

Posts.Content: Mar 6, 2009 06:58AM Denali wrote: Sending loads of positive thoughts your way.  Let us know what you find out, k? You're being a great proponant of mammograms and doing so much good!  You'll probably never know how many folks you affect!  Good for you!
Posts.Title: Biopsy results should be back tomorrow.. michele54 michele54

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2009 07:54PM Denali wrote: Hi there,  I'm so sorry you had to join this club.  But the more you read this board, the more you'll be inspired by all the warriors! Did you have surgery already?  Will you have a port surgically placed?  I had a mastectomy on Jan 16th and began chemo yesterday.  I'm on the same regimen:  taxotere, carboplatin and herceptin.  I started a thread on the Chemo board, so please join us there.  One other person just posted and she'll be starting her chemo March 1st.  Let's get through this together, k? I had a port in time for chemo and I swear, I never felt a thing!  The nurse sprayed and froze the skin on top of the port first and I never felt the needle go in.  She withdrew 3 vials of blood and then put in the IV.  Have someone go with you the first time.  I was a little more apprehensive than I thought I'd be.  But Xanex helps.  You DO have a prescription for Xanex, don't you?  Many of us use it and it's really helpful.  This a stressful time for all of us and we need all the help we can get! Please join us on the chemo board!
Posts.Title: just found out jkcrml Denali

Posts.Content: Jun 29, 2009 08:07AM Denali wrote: I had a mastectomy on my right breast last January and have never regretted it at all.  In fact the radiologist said she'd never known anyone to regret having a mastectomy.  You can always do reconstruction in the future.  I've decided no reconstruction for now.  I'm ok with a presthesis. Do you realize we are now officially Amazon Warriors??  The Amazons were women warriors who cut off their right breast so that they could better aim the bow and arrow.  Please inform your family of your new status!
Posts.Title: Help, IDC, Surgery Tomorrow Mamamari spar2
